fullDescription:
Father of Icelandic History - First Vernacular Historian

Ari Thorgilsson (Ari inn frodhi - 'Ari the Learned') stands as the founding figure of Icelandic historical writing. His Islendingabok (Book of Icelanders) established the methodology and standards for all subsequent Icelandic historiography. He was the first scholar to write Icelandic history in the vernacular Old Norse rather than Latin, creating a model that would enable the flourishing of saga literature in the following centuries.

Born in 1067 CE into an aristocratic Icelandic family, Ari was descended from some of the most prominent settlers of Iceland. His genealogy traced back to the Norwegian chieftains who colonized Iceland in the 9th and 10th centuries. He was raised and educated at Haukadalur in western Iceland under the tutelage of Hall Thorarinsson, who had known and spoken with individuals who remembered the conversion of Iceland to Christianity in 1000 CE. This connection to living memory gave Ari access to reliable oral traditions spanning generations.

Islendingabok (Book of Icelanders) - c. 1122-1133 CE

Ari's masterwork is a concise yet remarkably precise history of Iceland from its settlement (c. 870 CE) to his own time. Though brief (the surviving version covers only about 20 pages), its impact on Icelandic literature was immense. The work covers:

1. The Settlement of Iceland - The discovery and colonization by Norwegian settlers fleeing the consolidation of power under Harald Fairhair
2. The Establishment of the Althing (930 CE) - The founding of the Icelandic parliament, one of the oldest in the world
3. The Discovery of Greenland - Eirik the Red's exploration and settlement
4. The Conversion to Christianity (1000 CE) - The dramatic decision at the Althing to adopt Christianity
5. The Establishment of the Bishoprics - The organization of the Icelandic church
6. Church Laws and Chronology - The development of ecclesiastical governance

What distinguishes Ari's work is his rigorous methodology. He names his sources, acknowledges uncertainty, and carefully distinguishes between what he knows firsthand, what he learned from reliable witnesses, and what derives from earlier tradition. He writes: 'I have written what I learned from Teit, the son of Bishop Isleif, who was the wisest man I have known.'

Landnamabok (Book of Settlements)

Ari is credited as one of the original compilers of the Landnamabok, though the work has come down to us in later redactions. This extraordinary document records the settlement of Iceland, listing over 400 original settlers, their genealogies, and the lands they claimed. It represents a unique historical source for the colonization of Iceland and preserves countless details about early Icelandic society, beliefs, and the transition from paganism to Christianity.

The Landnamabok reveals the complex religious world of the settlement period - settlers who worshipped Thor, Freyr, or remained devoted to the old gods even as Christianity spread. It records sacred sites, temples, and the religious practices of the settlers, making it an invaluable source for understanding Norse religion in the last generations before conversion.

Historical Method and Legacy

Ari's approach to history was revolutionary for his time. Unlike many medieval chroniclers who uncritically accepted legendary accounts, Ari applied what might be called proto-historical criticism. He sought multiple witnesses, preferred recent and reliable testimony, and acknowledged the limits of his knowledge. His work influenced Snorri Sturluson and all subsequent Icelandic historians.

His decision to write in Old Norse rather than Latin was equally significant. By choosing the vernacular, Ari created a template that enabled the development of saga literature - the unique Icelandic contribution to world literature. Without Ari's precedent, the great family sagas and kings' sagas might never have been written in their characteristic Norse prose.

Ari died in 1148 CE, having established Icelandic historical writing as a scholarly discipline. His epithet 'inn frodhi' (the Learned) testifies to the respect in which he was held by his contemporaries and successors. Through his work, the memory of Iceland's settlement, its pagan past, and its conversion to Christianity was preserved for posterity.
